707116f-a.text:
Avenue U, south side, from East 63rd to East 64th Streets, showing
Public School No. 236.
Board of Education of the City of New York Early 1930's.
707116f-a.folder: Ave. U & 63rd St. E., Brooklyn, NY

702809f-a.text:
(1)
East 63rd Street, east side, between Ave. U, and Strickland Ave., showing the Schenck-Crooke house, which was also known as the Jan Martense Schenck house. The land was at one time known as Mill Island; probably named because of a mill that was built by Elbert Elbertsen Stoothoff about 1664. He sold in 1675 (not 1657) a half interest in the mill and island to Jan Martense Schenck. Bergen states: "The Schenck family built the house", and he gave the purchase year as 1657; hence, it is believed that the house was built about that year. If the Schencks built the house, it would date after 1675. Jan Martense evidently acquired title to the entire island, and mill as he devised both to his son Martin Janse Schenck by his will of 1688 9. This property was sold in 1785 by the heirs of John Schenck to Mrs. Susan Caton, a daughter of Joris Martense. Margaret, a daughter of Mrs. Susan Caton married general Philip Crooke. This mill became known as Crooke's mill and was demolished prior to 1881. The house still stands in 1929.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
A view of the front of the house.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(3)
The same, showing the rear, viewed westward.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(4)
The same, viewed northwestward.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

702810f-a.text:
East 63rd Street, east side, between Ave. U and Strickland Ave., showing the Schenck Crooke house.
1922.

702811f-b.text:
(1)
East 63rd Street, ea9,,jide, between Ave. U. and Strickland Ave., showing the Jean MartensefHouse, built in 1656 on Mill Island; later owned by General Phil. S. Crooke, later by Robert L. Crooke. It oame into the hands of the Flatbush East Real Estate concern in 1906, then to the Flatbush Improvement Co.; owned by the Atlantic Gulf and Pacific Co., since 1909. Note the out house gradually disappearing from the City of
New York to-day.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
